review_title: A wonderful NGO, a poor employer
pros: MSF is a wonderful NGO to work with, people are charismatic, enthusiastic, and the work in the field really gets done. Its is a wonderful place to work, make friends, and really feel that you make a difference. Even if many employees are frustrated by the lack of carrer management and not optimal HR management, most people come back to MSF when they have a chance, even at a lower pay, just because the work ethos is so positive
cons: MSF is a relatively bad employer at all levels (national staff in the field, expatriates and HQ staff). Don't expect more than the minimum. The "pay" comes from "doing the good" rather than being paid. The down side of it is that people leave after some time to get better paid elsewhere, so senior management is not necessarily filled with the most competent people

review_title: Beautiful Mission but challenging management environment and culture
pros:
Who does not love MSF's mission? Everybody at the organization feels proud to be part of MSF. 
Impact of work in the field is inspiring 
Great ethics, there's no corruption 
Strong principles
cons:
Difficult work-life balance
Management could be improved. As the organization has a very unique and specific culture, often times people are located into management positions without possessing the right skills nor the organization works to mentor or coach managers to perform well. The result is that most managers are performing high level activities without the right skills, leading teams to stress and limited guidance.  
Many people end up leaving the organization as a result of bad management practices
